ASSESSMENTS.title: Learner Self-reflection 2 – 24352 (v3)
ASSESSMENTS.subtitle: US 24352 – Safe working practices in a BCATS environment

questions.text: Compile a list of rules/codes of conduct that would ensure safe working practices in a BCATS environment. E.g. wear the appropriate eye protection at all times.
questions.hint: Include rules such as: always think about possible hazards and act accordingly; make a habit of always wearing appropriate PPE; do not wear loose or dangling clothing or jewellery; tie back long hair before operating machines.

questions.text: Q1 a-h: For each of the above points, describe the potential consequences that may occur if the safety rules/codes of conduct are not followed. E.g. Eye injury or blindness may occur if eye protection is not worn.
questions.hint: Think about what could happen if PPE is not worn, if loose clothing or jewellery is worn, or if hair is not tied back.

questions.text: Q2: Why should jandals never be worn on a work site?
questions.hint: Think about how much (or how little) protection jandals give compared to proper safety footwear.

questions.text:
Q3: Identify the hazard – What type of clothing would be a hazard to wear in the following situations?

Around heat or sparks
questions.hint: Clothing that is not protected from heat or sparks. Overalls and a welding jacket are needed for protection.

rubric.check: light (shirt|t.?shirt)|thin clothing|no overalls|no welding jacket|unprotected clothing

questions.text:
Q3: Identify the hazard – What type of clothing would be a hazard to wear in the following situations?

Around machinery such as lathes
questions.hint: Machine operators should wear close-fitting clothing. Do not wear ties or baggy sleeves.

rubric.check: baggy sleeves|loose sleeves|loose clothing|dangling clothing|dangling jewellery|dangling jewelry

questions.text:
Q3: Identify the hazard – What type of clothing would be a hazard to wear in the following situations?

When spraying paint
questions.hint: Spray painting or fibre-glassing requires overalls for complete body protection from paint, over-spray and chemicals.

(?:top|shirt)|normal clothes|everyday clothes|casual clothes|street clothes|school uniform)|uncovered skin|exposed skin|bare (?:arms?|legs?|skin))\b

questions.text: Q4: Identify the potential hazards of wearing long hair around machinery.
questions.hint: If hair gets caught in a machine, it will either be ripped out or peeled from your scalp (page 14).

questions.text: Q6: When nailing timber you should always wear eye protection. Describe an eye hazard associated with this activity.
questions.hint: A major cause of eye injuries is being struck in the eye by flying particles and objects, e.g. a nail ricocheting off a hammer face (page 27).

questions.text:
Q7: Describe the risks of not maintaining FIVE items of PPE.

1. Safety Glasses
questions.hint: Not cleaning the lenses daily risks secondary infection and impaired vision (page 51).

questions.text:
Q7: Describe the risks of not maintaining FIVE items of PPE.

2. Respiratory Protection
questions.hint: Not sterilising equipment and changing filters regularly risks developing lung diseases, cancer and other serious health-related problems (page 52).

questions.text:
Q7: Describe the risks of not maintaining FIVE items of PPE.

4. Hard Hat
questions.hint: Not checking for cracks or splits means the hat may fail to protect the head from injury (page 52).

rubric.check: head injur(y|ies)|skull fracture|brain injur(y|ies)|serious head damage

questions.text:
Q7: Describe the risks of not maintaining FIVE items of PPE.

5. Gloves
questions.hint: Not checking for tears or damage means they will not protect against chemicals or cuts (page 52).

questions.text:
Q8: Identify the hazards and select the most appropriate type of PPE that should be worn for each of the following situations.

(a) You are using an electric router to shape the edges of a rimu table top. Identify (at least) FOUR hazards you need to be protected from and the PPE that will help:
questions.hint: Think about: particles being flung into your eyes (safety glasses/goggles), wood dust (dust mask and/or extraction system), noise at 100 dB (ear plugs or ear muffs), loose clothing or long hair entanglement (close-fitting clothing and hair tied back), general workshop hazards/falling tools (safety shoes/boots).

questions.text:
Q8: Identify the hazards and select the most appropriate type of PPE that should be worn for each of the following situations.

(b) You are breaking up a concrete path using a sledge hammer. Identify at least THREE hazards you need to be protected from and the PPE that will help:
questions.hint: Think about: being struck in the eye by flying concrete debris (safety glasses/goggles), impact noise above 80 dB (ear plugs or ear muffs), falling or hard objects around your feet (safety shoes and boots with steel caps), coarse surfaces or hammer impacts on your hands (leather gloves), and poor lifting technique (correct technique).

poor lifting technique|bad lifting|back strain|back injur(y|ies)|ergonomic hazard

questions.text:
Q8: Identify the hazards and select the most appropriate type of PPE that should be worn for each of the following situations.

(c) You are turning a bowl on a wood lathe. Identify at least THREE hazards you need to be protected from and the PPE that will help:
questions.hint: Think about: high velocity particles (wide vision goggles or a full-face shield), wood dust (dust mask and/or extraction system), noise (ear plugs or ear muffs), loose clothing or long hair entanglement (close-fitting clothing and long hair tied back), and general workshop foot hazards (safety shoes/boots).

rubric.check: high velocity (particles?|chips?)|wide vision goggles?|full.?face shield|face shield

questions.text:
Q8: Identify the hazards and select the most appropriate type of PPE that should be worn for each of the following situations.

(d) You are unloading sheets of plywood off a truck and stacking them in a storage shed. Identify at least THREE hazards you need to be protected from and the PPE that will help.
questions.hint: Think about: poor lifting technique (ergonomic hazard – control is correct lifting technique), falling sheets (safety shoes and boots with steel caps), and sharp edges/coarse surfaces on the sheets (leather or reinforced poly-cotton gloves). Eye, respiratory, and hearing hazards are generally low risk here.
